intro: Schistocarpha longiligula var. seleri, commonly known as the Seler's long-beaked bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Boraginaceae and is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. Its flowers are tubular and bilaterally symmetrical, with five lobes that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. This variant is distinguished by its longer floral tubes compared to the typical form of Schistocarpha longiligula.
